results.title: Three African shorts
results.creator_credit: Mohamed Camara, Moussa Bathily, Sembene Ousmane, Dominique Andreani, Ministere de la Culture Senegal and Movimento
results.brief_description: Three short fictional films which provide an interesting overview of the thirty year history of film making in Black Africa. In “Denko” (1992) a mother will do anything to allow her blind son to lead a normal life. Guinean film-maker Mohamed Camara shot Denko in Burkina Faso and played the lead role himself. “Borom Sarret” (1963) is the first film made by a Black African. Senegalese director Ousmane Sembene takes a critical look at the social gulfs between poor and wealthy Senegalese. Shot in black and white, the film examines the day of a cart driver whose cart is confiscated when he ventures into the modern residential area of Dakar.”Certifcat D’Indigence” (1981) follows a similar theme. Senegalese director Moussa Bathily tells the heart rending story of a penniless woman trying to obtain medical care for her sick child. She travels across the city but is met with indiferrence and pedantic bureaucracy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mohamed Camara, Moussa Bathily, Sembene Ousmane, Dominique Andreani, Ministere de la Culture Senegal and Movimento

results.title: Three "I"s: a trio of personal films about Sweden by two Canadians and one Swede
results.creator_credit: Eric M Nilsson, Martin Duckworth, Mort Ransen, John Kemeny, Joseph Koenig, Wolf Koenig, National Film Board of Canada and Swedish Institute for Cultural Relations
results.brief_description: A film trilogy presenting impressions of Sweden by two Canadians and one Swede: Mort Ransen and Martin Duckworth of the National Film Board, and Swedish director Eric M. Nilsson. The film is composed of three films: “A Place for everything” - Eric Nilsson takes up the contrasts in the well-ordered Swedish society - order versus spontaneity; individual desires set against collective needs; subordinares vis-a-vis superiors. The young Swedes interviewed make a plea for independence, imagination and the discussion of existing conditions. “Falling from ladders” - Simply by putting about 20 Swedish men, women and young people in front of his camera and having them read aloud from the Statistical Year Book, filmmaker Mort Ransen has recorded a wide range of impressions of Sweden’s economic and social existence. Quotations vary from the whole gamut of exports and imports, marriages formed or dissolved, to the number of people who fall from ladders annually. (Award: Philadelphia) “Passing through Sweden” - A film critic of one of Sweden’s daily newspapers says of this film by Martin Duckworth, “Never before have I seen a film that so intensely interpreted the experience of Swedish surroundings…an ‘atmospheric film’ in which all the expression is in the pictures.”
results.title_for_label: Three “I”s: a trio of personal films about Sweden by two Canadians and one Swede
results.creator_credit_for_label: Eric M Nilsson, Martin Duckworth, Mort Ransen, John Kemeny, Joseph Koenig, Wolf Koenig, National Film Board of Canada and Swedish Institute for Cultural Relations

results.title: Thoughts on the future with George McRobie
results.creator_credit: Roger Hart, Colin Low and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: George McRobie, from Britain’s Intermediate Technology Group, and environmental specialists from Canadian universities, government and industry, discuss changes they foresee in the treatment of the Earth’s resources and the responsibility that falls to technology in making the world a better place to live. Some ecology-protective progress is illustrated in the film by engineers, and much more is promised for the future.

results.title: Those wild wild mushrooms
results.creator_credit: Art Makosinski, F Whitman Trecartin, Rex Tasker and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A happy-go-lucky film that should appeal to anyone interested in eating and stocking an inexpensive source of food. The information is built into a comic story about two experienced mushroom pickers and one novice, and their respective perambulations through the woods. Close-ups are supplemented by descriptions of the mushrooms, and a warning is issued not to pick what you can’t clearly identify, given the similarity between the poisonous and non-poisonous varieties.

results.title: Those who mourn
results.brief_description: An American wife experiences flashbacks of her husband’s death and of her past life with her husband. Shocked and traumatised she tries to understand what has happened, and what future lies before her.

results.title: Those awful hats
results.creator_credit: D.W. Griffith and American Mutoscope and Biograph Company
results.brief_description: Women wearing hats in the cinema can be rather annoying particularly if they obscure your line of vision. A comic short. Cast includes Mack Sennett, Flora Finch, Linda Arvidson, John R. Cumpson, George Gebhardt. Silent film with no intertitles.

results.title: Thoroughbred
results.creator_credit: John Watson, Pen Densham, Insight Productions (US) and Pyramid Films
results.brief_description: Opens with scenes of a race meeting, then moves through the whole cycle of a horse’s life: the birth in winter, foals playing in spring, yearlings being taken to sales as autumn approaches, the sales arena and bidding for the livestock, the patient year of training, and lastly, a slow motion race sequence.
